etymology.description: 大 ‘man’ + 口 ‘mouth/object’; top later simplified to 土 and bottom to 厶; conservative variant 厺.
etymology.interpretation: A person combined with an opening suggests departing from a place or taking something out, yielding senses like ‘go’ and ‘remove’. Some traditions also relate it to lips parting (opening), which naturally extends to movement away or separation.

examples.chinese: 我们明天去北京(我們明天去北京)。
examples.english: We are going to Beijing tomorrow.

examples.chinese: 请把这个错误去掉(請把這個錯誤去掉)。
我得去一趟商店(我得去一趟商店)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ děi qù yí tàng shāngdiàn.
examples.english: I need to make a trip to the store.
